If the recipient does not give up what they have taken, one should not encourage their relatives.
If the beggar has something they seek and arouses an attitude of non-acceptance, one should not encourage them with the king's wealth, possessions, or house.
If the beggar has something they seek, their mind is no different.

If someone comes wishing to obtain something, such as elephants, horses, carriages, clothing, head, eyes, marrow, brain, eyes, ears, nose, mouth, limbs, hands, feet, skin, hair, flesh, or blood, they give it to them according to their requests, without any resentment in their minds, and give with patience;

From this point on, they wish to gather in the various beings, and when they attain Buddhahood, they expound the scriptures and Dharma for them, enabling them to quickly understand.'
If, son of a great clan!
If a bodhisattva gives rise to such a mind, this is called a bodhisattva who does not spare their life;

They do not spare their bodies and lives, and do not commit any evil. They do not harm life to nourish their bodies, and do not commit unwholesomeness for the sake of life. Even if someone were to cut, destroy, take, or carry it away, one should not give rise to thoughts, and should not be attached to the body or cherish life. I do not resent them or give rise to anger towards them, but rather increase compassion towards those beings.

There is a great medicinal tree, from which its roots, trunk, joints, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits are all taken. Establishing in the Dharma;
Associating with good friends;
